main event: An observer spotted a round, glowing object in the sky near Omaha, Nebraska on January 9, 1950.
interesting points: The object was about 6-8 times the size of a star, with a brilliant white light in the center and dimmer lights on each side in a horizontal plane.
The object's color changed from green to purple to blue to white.
The object was observed for about 15 minutes and its movement was described as westerly with constantly increasing altitude.
The observer used binoculars to observe the object, which were found to provide about 5x magnification.
The behavior and course of the object were correlated with the predicted celestial track of the first magnitude star Circus, and the initial rapid movement was attributed to temperature inversions.
witnesses: multiple observers, including a supervisor of a teletype maintenance shop, a lieutenant, and a captain
